H0.text: Roots contain the most of the special parts that capture sunlight to make food in a plant.

H1.text: Stems are the parts of a plant where most of the light‑capturing cells that use sunlight to make food are found.

H2.text: Leaves contain the most of the special parts of plant cells that capture sunlight and use it to make food.

H3.text: Flowers are the location where most of the plant's light‑capturing parts—used by plant cells to convert sunlight into food—are found.

A4.text: the majority of those are found in specially adapted structures called leaves

A5.text: the cells in the interior tissues of a leaf, called the mesophyll, can contain between 450,000 and 800,000 chloroplasts for every square millimeter of leaf
